The Project will directly benefit about 45,300 farm households
or  12  percent  of  the  rural  population  in  12  districts  in  the
Midwestern and Far Western development regions. There will
be notable changes in farmers' cropping patterns and intensity
through  the  introduction  of  secondary  crops.  Under  the
Project,  farmers  will  gradually  adopt  improved  seeds  and
technology through their groups. The annual farm income will
increase  under  the  Project  by  about  NRs5,300  ($77),  or  44
percent in the lowland region, while in the hilly region the gain
will  be  about  NRs6,300  ($91),  or  by  66  percent.  The  gain  in
net income is higher in the hilly region because of the greater
potential  for  growing  horticultural  crops  in  the  hills.  Based  on
the  aggregate  costs  and  benefits,  the  Project  will  have  a
financial  internal  rate  of  return  of  16.1  percent  and  an
economic internal rate of return of 19.6 percent. The Project is
highly  justified  from  a  poverty  perspective  as  substantial
benefits will accrue to rural people, who are below or near the
poverty line. Sensitivity analyses conducted on cost overruns,
decreases in benefits, and a combination of the two show the
Project to remain viable.

III.  BACKGROUND

Sector Description

A.
 

1. 

Agriculture Sector

 
3.
Nepal  has  unique  topographic  characteristics  with  its  altitude  increasing  rapidly  from
about  100  meters  (m)  above  mean  sea  level  in  the  south  to  over  8,800  m  in  the  Himalayan
mountains  in  the  north,  within  about  200  kilometers.  Based  on  this  difference  in  altitude,  the
country  is  broadly  divided  into  three  ecological  regions,  which  are  lowland  (Terai),3  hilly,  and
mountainous regions. Each region has its own flora, fauna, and climate. The Terai has alluvial
soils  and  is  the  main  area  for  food-grain  production.  The  hilly  region  has  an  altitude  ranging
from 250 m to 4,000 m above mean sea level and is less densely populated with a series of
valleys. The mountainous region is least populated and has the lowest intensity of agricultural
activities.  The  hilly  and  mountainous  regions  are  suited  to  the  production  of  various
horticultural  crops.  Maximum  and  minimum  temperatures  differ  widely  by  altitude  and  by
month.  About  60  to  80  percent  of  annual  precipitation  is  concentrated  during  the  monsoon
season between June and September.

In  view  of  the  importance  of  agriculture,  the  sector's  growth  is  essential  for  achieving
the national objective of poverty reduction. High priority is given to agriculture, with about one
quarter of the Government's development budget being allocated to the sector during the last
five  years.  However,  the  average  growth  rate  in  the  agriculture  sector  in  the  1990s  was
disappointingly low at about 2.2 percent per annum, which was less than the average rate of
population growth at 2.3 percent per annum during the same period. As a result, the per capita
food-grain production declined from 315 kilograms in fiscal year (FY)1991 to 290 kilograms in
FY1998.  The  yields  of  major  crops  in  Nepal  have  been  low  and  stagnant  since  the  1960s,
while  yields  in  other  South  Asian  countries  improved  significantly.  Nepal  did  not  sufficiently
benefit from improved agricultural technology. The average yields of unhulled rice and wheat in
Nepal in the 1990s are estimated at 2.31 and 1.46 tons/ha, respectively. These are lower than
those of other countries in South Asia by 10 to 40 percent. Area, production, and yield of major
crops in South Asia and in the Midwestern and Far Western development regions in Nepal are
shown in Appendix 2.

The Government commenced implementing of the Agriculture Perspective Plan (APP)5
6.
to  reverse  this  trend  and  promote  agricultural  production  through  policy  and  institutional
reforms  to  liberalize  the  agriculture  sector.  The  APP  was  formulated  in  a  highly  consultative
and  participatory  manner  that  has  not  been  used  before  in  Nepal  and  reflects  a  wide
consensus  among  key  stakeholders.  The  APP's  objectives  are  to  (i)  accelerate  agricultural
growth through focused investment and increased factor productivity, (ii) alleviate poverty and
improve  rural  livelihoods,  and  (iii)  transform  a  subsistence-oriented  agriculture  into  a

advantages.  The  APP  emphasizes  the  importance  of  priority  inputs  as  a  package,  including
fertilizer,  irrigation,  technology,  and  rural  infrastructure.  The  APP  aims  at  developing  the
lowland  region  through  the  green  revolution  package  with  a  combination  of  improved  seeds,
fertilizer, and controlled water supply for intensified crop production. The strategy for the hilly
and  mountainous  regions  emphasizes  the  need  to  develop  high  value  agricultural  products.
These  products  offer  the  opportunity  for  high  income  per  unit  area,  which  is  particularly
important  where  agricultural  land  is  scarce.  The  APP  also  stresses  the  need  for  greatly
expanded agricultural trade between the hilly and mountainous regions and the lowland region,
in  view  of  the  potential  complementarity  between  them.  To  establish  such  linkage,  the  APP
calls for a market-oriented approach based on private sector initiatives.

2.

Secondary Crops

9.
Various  secondary  crops,  also  called  subsidiary  crops,  cover  about  40  percent  of  the
total cropped area, and provide vital nutritional supplements such as vegetable protein, vitamins,
and minerals for people’s diet in a country where more than 50 percent of children under three
years of age suffer from malnutrition. These crops constitute important sources of cash income
for farmers and contribute 10-30 percent of their average household income. Secondary crops
include  cereal  crops  except  for  rice  and  wheat,  and  a  large  number  of  cash  crops  such  as
pulses, oilseeds, spices, vegetables, and fruits.

10.
The typical cropping patterns in the lowlands include (i) rice followed by rice, wheat, or
mustard  seeds  under  irrigation;  and  (ii)  rice  or  maize  followed  by  lentil,  chickpea,  or  fallow
under  rainfed  conditions.  Production  of  sugarcane  and  tropical  fruits  such  as  bananas  and
mangoes is also popular in the region. On the other hand, the hilly and mountainous regions
have a diverse range of cropping patterns, including rice, maize, or millet followed by wheat,
lentil,  soybean,  vegetables,  mustard  seed,  or  fallow.  Maize  and  millet  are  important  cereal
crops  in  these  regions  with  terracing  along  valleys.  All  the  food-deficit  areas  are  in  hilly
districts, which do not have comparative advantages in producing major cereal crops because
of  their  climate  and  limited  arable  land.  The  APP  emphasizes  complementarity  between
ecological  regions,  and  trade  between  these  regions  will  benefit  the  food-deficit  districts  by
enabling  them  to  obtain  more  food  through  increased  cash  income.  It  will  also  benefit  the
lowland region by providing a market for its food grains.

11.
Farmers use improved seeds of vegetables and fruits, which are mainly produced and
packed in Japan and Europe, and imported through India by private traders. Local production
of these seeds is being mainly done at the regional agricultural research stations of the Nepal
Agricultural Research Council (NARC). Farmers prefer imported seeds for their regular

12.
The  marketing  potential  is  good  in  the  domestic  market,  primarily  in  Kathmandu,  for
fresh  vegetables  and  fruits  because  of  climatic  differences  between  regions  and  rapid

statistics on the marketing of agricultural products are scarce. However, domestic vegetables
and fruits are increasingly preferred to imports from India. Based on the figures obtained from
the Marketing Division of the Department of Agriculture (DOA), Nepal imported about 100,000
tons  of  vegetables  in  1999  mainly  from  India,  which  constitutes  only  about  7  percent  of  the
total domestic consumption. The average daily inflow of fruits and vegetables from the western
regions  of  Nepal  into  major  wholesale  markets  in  Kathmandu  has  been  increasing  and  now
amounts  to  about  190  tons,  which  constitutes  about  50  percent  of  the  total  inflow.7  External
markets,  mainly  in  India,  exist  for  cash  crops  such  as  ginger,  and  bulk  products  such  as
pulses,  maize,  and  lentils.  Pulses,  ginger,  and  cardamon  are  the  major  secondary  crops
exported to India. The export potential will be enhanced with improvements in the reliability of

At times, farmers realize a marketable surplus due to favorable weather conditions or
13.
need to sell their produce for cash to pay for consumption or other exigencies. Unfortunately,
no effective market information systems exist, and thus farmers often have to sell their produce
to  local  traders  or  agents  at  prices  that  are  lower  than  the  prevailing  market  prices.  This
problem is more pronounced for secondary crops, which are produced in small quantities. Sale
in  small  quantities  at  market  centers  that  are  away  from  villages  involves  higher  transaction
costs  and  gives  little  incentive  to  look  for  better  prices  elsewhere.  Few  formal  local  market
facilities  are  available  in  remote  areas.  Small-scale  farmers  often  find  it  difficult  to  access
markets,  and  do  not  have  the  continuity  of  supply  to  satisfy  wholesalers,  who  in  turn  cannot
predict  adequate  volume  and  prices  effectively.  In  some  areas,  however,  a  few  farmers'
associations, with assistance from NGOs and the district staff of DOA, have taken initiatives in
group  marketing  of  farm  produce.  The  formation  of  these  associations  needs  to  be
encouraged, and there is an increasingly strong demand among farmers for better access to
market information on their products so that they can effectively respond to the current market
conditions.

Poverty in Nepal

17.
The  country’s  population  reached  approximately  22  million  in  1998,  evenly  divided  by
gender.  The  ratio  of  population  to  arable  land  is  one  of  the  world’s  highest  at  approximately
600 persons per square kilometer. In Nepal, concern is increasing about the high incidence of
poverty among the rural population despite the Government’s large development expenditures in
the past with assistance from external funding agencies. The recent estimate indicates that 42
percent of the country’s total population were below the poverty line.8 According to the Human
Development Report of the United Nations Development Programme for 2000, Nepal is ranked
144th out of 174 countries, with its human development index estimated at 0.474. The poverty
incidence is highest in the rural areas and in remote districts. Against this background, poverty
reduction  is  the  primary  objective  of  the  Government’s  development  policy,  as  indicated  in  its
Ninth Plan and the APP (para. 6).

The  country’s  socioeconomic  structure  is  based  on  subsistence  agriculture  with  high
18.
underemployment  and  low  agricultural  productivity.  Over  the  last  two  decades,  average  life
expectancy  in  Nepal  has  increased  by  13.5  years,  to  a  national  life  expectancy  of  57  years,
which  is  the  lowest  in  South  Asia.  The  life  expectancy  rate  for  women  is  lower  than  that  for
men. Infant mortality continues to be high, with 1 in every 10 children dying in infancy. Infants
in the rural areas are exposed to higher risk of death than those in urban areas, and infants in
the mountainous region are more than twice as likely to die as those in the hilly and lowland
regions.9 Nepal also has one of the highest incidence of maternal mortality in the world as well
as a high rate of morbidity. Malnutrition is widespread, with over half of all households suffering
from some degree of food insecurity.

19.
On  average,  food  expenditure  accounts  for  62  percent  of  household  income,  leaving
insufficient  income  for  spending  on  health,  education,  and  other  necessities.  The  gender
disparity in income is acute resulting from the control of income by the male head of household
and the near total lack of property rights for women. The disparity in assets and income often
has  a  detrimental  effect  on  household  health,  nutrition,  education,  and  overall  standard  of
living.  To  have  significant  impact  on  poverty  reduction  in  Nepal,  more  emphasis  needs  to  be
placed on the policies and programs that emphasize capacity building for the poor so they can
participate  in  the  development  process  through  NGOs,  community-based  organizations
(CBOs), and local governments. It is also important that maximum attention is given to women
through, among other things, appropriate support for their role in agriculture.

5.

Gender and Agricultural Development

20. Women's  roles  are  critical  in  agricultural  production  in  Nepal.  However,  the  value  of
such  roles  has  been  largely  diminished,  and  women  have  had  less  access  than  men  to  the
development  process  and  the  resulting  benefits.  Norms  of  hierarchy  and  cultural  notions  of
female and male roles govern the specific ways in which work is shared. The prevailing gender
division of labor makes men responsible for plowing while women are held responsible for the
ensuing  tasks.  As  a  result,  regardless  of  the  crop  that  is  being  cultivated,  labor  inputs  for
planting,  composting,  applying  manure,  transplanting,  weeding,  and  postharvest  activities
including seed selection and storing are mainly provided by women.

21.
DOA’s  training  programs  and  extension  services  have  had  little  impact  on  the
productivity of rural women because of (i) extension services not fully taking into account the
gender division of labor in the agricultural production cycle, (ii) a gender bias toward men in the
provision  of  training  and  information,  and  (iii)  the  absence  of  institutional  support  to  women
farmer groups. Training on subjects like seed trial, selection, and planting should be directed to
women. Usually, men hold title to land. As a result, women’s access to formal credit is limited.
Men generally control the marketing of agricultural surpluses, and the income from the sale of
crops  remains  with  men.  Women  are  able  to  sell  or  barter  a  small  amount  of  grains  to  meet
some of their household needs.

22.
Overall, women account for about 20 percent of farmer group members and less than 2
percent  of  the  group  leadership.  Women  are  encouraged  by  the  DOA's  district  staff  to
participate  in  farmer  groups  and  DOA's  training  programs.  However,  the  degree  of  women’s
participation and interactions between men and women is still to a great extent determined by

sociocultural  traditions.  Particularly  in  the  lowland  region,  women  prefer  to  participate  in
women-only  groups  due  to  cultural  barriers.  These  women-only  groups  have  been  formed
around specific crops such as ginger, vegetables, and mushrooms.

Vegetable  cultivation  has  emerged  as  a  significant  activity  for  marginal  farm
23.
households  with  less  than  0.25  ha  of  land.  Vegetables  with  short  gestation  periods  yield  (i)
quick  and  high  returns  when  marketed,  (ii)  a  regular  source  of  income  for  poor  households,
and  (iii)  nutritional  supplements.  Women  with  access  to  water  and  to  local  markets  are
motivated to invest more time in vegetable production in their kitchen gardens, as they are able
to  reconcile  these  activities  with  their  household  work.  Women  in  the  hilly  region  directly
control outputs of homestead vegetable production and actively bring their products to nearby
markets.  Facilitating  women's  involvement  in  marketing  their  products  will  contribute  to
improving women's position in their households since the person who markets the produce has
a  larger  control  over  cash  income.  The  improvement  of  women’s  access  to  marketing  of
commercial crops is crucial in addressing gender issues in agriculture.

 IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT

Rationale

 
A. 
 
39.
Nepal is one of the lowest-income countries in the world with 42 percent of the country’s
population  living  below  the  poverty  line.  Poverty  incidence  is  high  in  the  Midwestern  and  Far
Western development regions, where the Project will be implemented, estimated at 59 percent
and  65  percent  respectively  (footnote  9).  Nepal’s  agriculture  depends  largely  on  subsistence-
oriented food-grain production. However, the secondary crops constitute important sources of
farmers'  cash  income,  which  can  be  used  for  purchasing  staple  foods,  and  vital  nutritional
supplements.  Rapid  improvements  in  the  vehicular  access  through  ADB-financed  projects14
will further enhance the potential for the production and marketing of secondary crops in these
development regions.

40.
The Government requested ADB to provide a follow-on undertaking to the SCDP (para.
31)  in  Nepal's  Midwestern  and  Far  Western  development  regions.  The  lack  of  effective
agricultural extension services and a weak linkage between extension and research in the field
are still major constraints to production and marketing of secondary crops in these regions. To
provide  more  effective  research  and  extension  services  for  the  client  farmers  under  the
Project,  the  Government  and  ADB  agreed  to  adopt  the  group  formation  and  strengthening
processes that have been effectively practiced by NGOs and CBOs in Nepal, and to promote
the  involvement  of  private  service  providers.  Important  policy  and  institutional  reforms,  which
were recently introduced on the supply side of agricultural inputs in line with the Government's
APP,  are  expected  to  increase  production  with  the  improved  dissemination  of  appropriate
production technologies and marketing information under the Project. The Project addresses the
issue of food security by providing farmers with cash income and important nutritional sources,
and  landless  laborers  with  increased  employment  opportunities  through  more  intensive
cropping activities. The Project will fit in ADB’s country operational strategy for Nepal to reduce
poverty by facilitating the transformation of rural communities for sustainable growth and better
living standards.

private  extension  services,  (iii)  promotion  of  client-oriented  research,  and  (iv)  project
management support. The Project will cover 12 districts in phases (see Map). These districts
have  been  selected  based  on  criteria  that  include  (i)  districts  covered  under  the  SCDP,  (ii)
districts  where  similar  activities  were  implemented  in  the  past  under  other  projects,  (iii)
available  vehicular  access  to  district  headquarters,  (iv)  potential  for  the  production  and
marketing  of  secondary  crops,  and  (v)  food  self-sufficiency  status.  The  security  situation  in
these districts was fully considered and will be closely monitored during project implementation
in consultation with other external funding agencies. The possibility of including other districts
in  the  two  development  regions  may  be  considered  during  the  midterm  review  if  additional
districts  meet  the  criteria  and  project  activities  are  progressing  well  in  the  12  districts.  The
Project  aims  at  gradually  promoting  the  provision  of  private  extension  services  in  the  project
area.

The  Project  focuses  on  secondary  crops  that  have  good  potential  for  increased
43.
production and marketing. The marketing potential of various secondary crops was assessed
during  project  formulation  through  a  series  of  interviews  and  regional  workshops  with  farmer
groups,  dealers  of  agricultural  inputs  and  outputs,  and  the  staff  of  central  and  local
administrations.  Important  crops  identified  during  this  process  include  maize,  oilseed,  lentil,
chickpea,  pigeon  pea,  soybean,  and  sunflower.  In  addition,  horticultural  crops  including
vegetables and fruits are considered to have good potential if extension services and market
information  systems  are  improved.  Under  the  Project,  farmers  will  be  encouraged  to  use  the
existing  savings  and  credit  organizations  in  the  project  area  so  that  the  members  of  farmer
groups will have easier access to the finance required for increased production and marketing
of  secondary  crops.  There  is  adequate  liquidity  available  for  rural  credit  in  the  project  area
through  formal  and  informal  financial  institutions,  including  the  existing  lines  of  credit  under
ADB's ongoing Rural Microfinance Project.15

47.
The strengthening of existing farmer groups and the formation of new groups will be the
first step to develop a sustainable framework for improved agricultural extension. The existing
farmer groups include those of water users, forest users, vegetable growers, crop producers,
livestock  farmers,  savings  and  credit  organizations,  and  women's  and  youth  groups.  These
groups  will  be  integrated  into  the  Project  to  the  maximum  extent  possible  in  order  to  avoid
duplication  of  group  formation  activities.  Only  where  groups  are  not  available  will  the  Project
support  the  formation  of  new  farmer  groups.  The  average  size  of  farmer  groups  will  largely
depend  on  the  type  of  groups  used,  but  is  expected  to  be  about  25  farmers  in  the  lowland
region and about 20 farmers in the hilly region. Based on the experience of DOA and CBOs in
the project area, these averages are considered to be appropriate and manageable for group
sustainability and the delivery of extension services and training. Sufficient flexibility should be
allowed in new group formation to determine their size based on local conditions. Each pocket
area for field crops is expected to have about 20 farmer groups in the lowland region and 15
groups in the hilly region, and a pocket area for fruits or vegetables will have about 4 groups in
both lowland and hilly regions.

DOA's agricultural extension services, including technical training, crop demonstrations,
and foundation seed production, will be provided for farmer groups in the project area. Training
programs  for  farmer  groups  and  women's  farmer  groups  will  be  conducted  by  JTs  and  JTAs
under  the  Project  on  (i)  the  use  of  improved  seeds  and  other  agricultural  inputs  for  the
production of secondary crops; (ii) postharvest operations, including the availability and use of
storage  facilities;  (iii)  marketing of secondary crops; and (iv) rural finance. Training programs
on other subjects will be considered based on the demand from farmer groups and in view of
other training programs, which farmers receive from other projects and NGOs. Women will be

particularly  encouraged  to  participate  in  training  on  group  marketing  of  secondary  crops  as
they  have  greater  responsibility  for  marketing  decisions.  Field  team  supervisors  will  also
provide  training  for  farmer  groups  and  women  farmer  groups  on  group  management,  self-
monitoring  of  group  activities,  registration  as  cooperatives,  and  group  procurement  of  inputs
and marketing.

To promote interactions between private dealers and processors, and farmers, DADOs
will  organize  agricultural  fairs  in  the  project  area  in  collaboration  with  local  chambers  of
commerce  and  industry.  The  existing  collection  centers  and  local  markets  in  the  selected
production  pocket  areas  will  be  rehabilitated  based  on  the  requests  from  farmer  groups  and
through  consultations  with  district  and  village  development  committees.  Under  the  Project,
regional facilities will be strengthened for effective collection and dissemination of information
on local markets through (i) collaboration with the existing information network, such as that of
the  Agro-enterprise  Center  of  the  Federation  of  Nepalese  Chambers  of  Commerce  and
Industry; (ii) improvement of communications facilities, including the increased use of facsimile
and e-mail; and (iii) provision of service vehicles where necessary. The consultants recruited
under  the  Project  will  assist  DADOs  in  improving  the  market  information  system,  making  the

research for products of good marketing potential.

b.

Promotion of Private Extension Services

50.
The  Project  will  promote  the  use  of  private  service  providers,  including  NGOs  and
CBOs,  to  form  and  strengthen  farmer  groups  and  provide  agricultural  extension  services  for
them.  As  the  number  and  availability  of  such  private  service  providers  is  limited,  the  private
extension services will be introduced gradually into the Project. The selection and awarding of
contracts to these service providers will be done by the PCU or the concerned regional director

programs  for  increasing  social  awareness  and  skills  of  agricultural  laborers  who  had  been
working  under  the  bonded  labor  practices.17  There  is  an  urgent  need  for  providing  these
laborers with adequate economic means for self-reliance.

Promotion of Client-Oriented Research

The  Project  will  support  research  proposals  on  the  priority  subjects  identified  for  the
52.
project area. The quarterly meetings of the regional technical working groups and the monthly
meetings  of  the  district  agricultural  development  committees  will  be  used  for  identifying  high
priority subjects for research, thereby facilitating client-oriented research activities (paras. 63-
64).  Such  research  proposals  will  be  invited  from  public  and  private  institutions,  including
NARC,  the  Institute  of  Agricultural  and  Animal  Sciences,  other  Government  agencies,
universities,  colleges,  private  companies,  and  NGOs.  The  Project  will  be  focused  on  the
gradual commercialization of agriculture through crop diversification in the project area. Thus,
the  starting  point  for  all  activities  will  be  market  research  to  establish  what  can  profitably  be
sold and in which markets. Research activities will then aim at (i) identifying which production
pocket area can best meet the demand of each market, (ii) identifying or developing suitable
varieties and agronomic practices to meet this demand, and (iii) using the extension service to
bring these varieties and practices to the attention of farmer groups.

53.
These  research  proposals  will  be  financed  under  the  Project  through  contributions  to
the  NARDF  (para.  36),  which  will  be  established  by  the  Government  to  institutionalize  a
competitive  funding  system  for  agricultural  research  proposals.  This  system  was  originally

through new legislation (para. 64). As an interim measure, it was agreed that the Government

national  committee  to  administer  funds  for  agricultural  research  and  development.  Loan
proceeds  will  not  be  withdrawn  for  this  component  until  the  Government  establishes  this
committee,  which  will  comprise  seven  representatives  of  the  Government,  civil  society  and

agricultural  research  system  to  be  more  responsive;  minimize  unnecessary  interference;  and
involve  the  eventual  clients  in  the  identification  of  problems,  selection  of  proposals,  and
funding of research activities.

Environmental Measures

86.
A field survey for an initial environmental examination (IEE) was carried out from June
to July 1999 in the project area. Degradation of soil fertility is an important environmental issue
related to the Project. Maintenance of soil fertility is traditionally left to natural processes and
often  carried  out  by  farmers  using  farmyard  manure.  With  the  introduction  of  intensified
cropping,  there  will  be  an  increased  extraction  of  nutrients,  and  the  level  of  fertility
maintenance  may  not  be  sufficient.  Use  of  chemical  fertilizers  is  likely  to  increase  in  the
production  pocket  areas  to  supplement  the  soil  fertility.  Although  the  average  amount  of
fertilizers used in Nepal is very low at about 30 kilograms per ha, the excessive and improper
use  of  chemical  fertilizers  in  some  areas  could  affect  water  bodies,  wetlands,  and  soil.
Introduction of an integrated plant nutrient management system will be encouraged under the
Project  to  avoid  the  excessive  use  of  chemical  fertilizers.  Where  chemical  fertilizers  are
necessary,  their  appropriate  use  will  be  promoted  through  training  and  demonstration
activities.  Under  the  Project,  soil  testing  kits  and  soil  augers  will  be  procured  for  ASCs  and
ASSCs so that soil samples can be more easily obtained for analysis in the field.

Similarly,  soil  erosion  is  a  common  environmental  problem  that  may  be  caused  by
87.
increased development activities in the project area. Soil erosion will have wide environmental
consequences,  including  loss  of  fertility  and  frequent  floods,  unless  proper  conservation
measures such as terracing are taken, particularly in the hilly region. Slope, rainfall, vegetation
cover, and human activities all need to be taken into account for environmental protection

 26

under the Project. Training and awareness programs for farmer groups will include the relevant
subjects  on  low-cost  soil  conservation  techniques.  The  use  of  chemical  pesticides  can  affect
the  environment  and  public  health  through  their  adverse  impact  on  soil  fauna  and  micro-
organisms,  by  killing  untargeted  species;  and  on  human,  farm  animals,  and  food.  Adverse
impact  can  arise  from  the  application  of  the  wrong  pesticides,  excessive  amounts,  and
inappropriate  storage;  and  careless  disposal  of  containers.  The  inadequate  knowledge  of
integrated pest management will be addressed under the training programs of the Project for

A.

Financial and Economic Analyses

1. 

Financial Analysis

a.

Outreach

Financial  analysis  was  based  on  the  indicative  cropping  patterns  for  the  aggregate  of
94.
the  production  pocket  areas  that  will  benefit  under  the  Project.  The  benefits  included  in  the
analysis were those derived from incremental production of marketable produce and a switch
to  alternative  higher  value  crops.  No  account  was  taken  of  the  increased  prices  that  farmers
may  obtain  for  their  produce  through  improved  marketing  and  postharvesting  processes,
although  these  are  considered  to  be  substantial.  The  Project  will  yield  quantifiable  direct
benefits  through  pocket  area  development  for  45,300  farmers  or  about  12  percent  of  the
estimated 389,900 farmers in 12 districts.20 The average farm size in the lowland region is 1.4
ha for field crops and 1.0 ha for horticulture. In the hilly region, the average farm size is 0.5 ha
for  both  field  and  horticultural  crops.  However,  most  project  beneficiaries  are  expected  to  be
small  and  marginal  farmers.  Some  changes  in  the  cropping  patterns  of  these  farmers  will  be
introduced under the Project. In the lowland region, at present, 88 percent of the cropped area
is  for  field  crops  while  the  remaining  area  is  for  horticultural  crops.  These  proportions  are
expected to change through a reduction in field crops and the increase in horticultural crops in
the selected production pocket areas under the Project. In the hilly region, the current use of
90  percent  for  field  crops  and  10  percent  for  horticulture  will  also  change.  Increases  in
vegetables  and  fruits  will  result  largely  from  shifts  out  of  subsistence-oriented  food  crops  in
response  to  the  increasing  marketing  potential  for  the  secondary  crops.  In  addition,  with
improved extension services and the introduction of secondary crops during winter (November-
February),  cropping  intensities  will  increase.  The  details  of  financial  analysis  are  included  in
Appendix 11.

95.
Under  the  Project,  farmers  will  gradually  change  their  cropping  patterns  with  the  total
area of land affected by the Project increasing each year as pocket areas are developed, and
farmers utilize project services. New leguminous crops such as peanuts, lentil, and peas, and
other secondary crops will gradually replace wheat and maize. Particularly in the hilly region,
the  area  currently  in  millet,  maize,  and  wheat  will  be  converted  into  a  broad  range  and
expanded area of vegetables, including vegetable seeds, and an increased area in citrus fruits.
The  total  area  cropped  will  increase  as  cropping  intensity  increases.  The  impact  of  farmers'
adoption of new packages is assumed to be fully realized four years after their introduction.

b. 

Impact on Beneficiaries

fruits  for  the  lowland  and  hilly  regions,  and  for  both  without-  and  with-Project  situations.
Revenues  are  based  on  farmgate  prices.  The  with-Project  budgets  do  not  include  increased
use of inputs or higher crop yields as the focus is on crop diversification. The expected

Based on these crop budgets, indicative 0.5 ha farm models have been formulated for
the lowland and hilly regions to assess possible changes in farm income between the without-

cash crops with good marketing potential like fresh vegetables, by converting areas previously
used for millet and wheat production. The gain in net income is higher in the hilly region than in
the lowland region because of higher potential for growing horticultural crops in the hills. The
income  analysis  also  shows  that  the  return  on  daily  family  labor  will  be  substantially  higher
than the basic wage rate, which is expected to be in the range of NRs50-75. Under the Project,
farmers are also expected to change their combination of crops more frequently in response to
changes in local market conditions with better access to accurate information on local markets.

expected to accrue to women. Discussions in the field suggest that any incremental income is
widely regarded as  household income and will improve the well-being of the whole household.
A positive impact of the Project on the generation of on-farm income earning opportunities will
reduce migration of male household members seeking work outside the project area.

B. 

Environment

102. Project activities are likely to generate a positive environmental impact. The Project will
result in increased cropping intensity, which will increase the amount of vegetative cover and
improve soil conservation. Various leguminous crops that will be adopted under the Project will
help maintain soil fertility, which is another environmental benefit. Under the Project, integrated
pest  management  and  integrated  plant  nutrition  management  will  be  encouraged  for
production pocket areas. The use of agricultural chemicals is likely to increase particularly for
horticultural  crops,  but  the  adverse  environmental  impact  will  be  minimized  through  the
provision of appropriate training and awareness programs for farmer groups.

103. PIUs'  monitoring  officers  will  be  responsible  for  work  activities  on  environmental
management  with  a  particular  emphasis  on  the  provision  of  adequate  information  for  the
pocket areas to ensure more efficient environmental management. They will also report to the
PCU about the environmental aspects of the pocket areas and recommend specific measures
for improvements. PIUs will regularly monitor the different environmental impacts including (i)
changes in vegetative cover in the project area; (ii) soil test records and nutrient level; (iii) type,
quantity,  and  method  of  use  of  chemical  fertilizers;  (iv)  pollution  status  including  pesticide
residue  of  wetlands;  (v)  water  level  of  local  wells  and  ponds;  (vi)  density  and  discharge  of
shallow  tube  wells;  (vii)  the  number  of  farmers  receiving  environmental  training;  (viii)  erosion
and landslide incident; (ix) silt accumulation in farmlands; and (x) slope and forest conditions.
Institutionalizing these functions into PIUs will ensure that the adverse environmental impacts
of project activities will be minimized.

C.

Social Dimensions

1. 

Rural Poverty

The  Project  will  address  important  social  issues  in  the  project  area.  The  Project  will
104.
adopt  a  farmer  group  approach,  which  is  well  established  as  an  effective  system  for
strengthening  the  capability  of  marginal  and  small  farmers,  and  for  the  delivery  of  improved
agricultural  technology  and  market  information.  The  involvement  of  private  service  providers,
including national and local NGOs, will enhance outreach to project beneficiaries. The private
service providers to be contracted under the Project have long experience in dealing with small
and  marginal  farmers,  and  supporting  weak  and  disadvantaged  groups  of  people  in  rural
areas.

105. Under  the  Project,  the  increased  production  and  marketing  of  secondary  crops  will
provide  farmers  with  increased  cash  income.  The  increased  income  usually  leads  to  (i)  a
withdrawal  of  family  members  from  off-farm  casual  labor  and  increased  employment  on  their
own land, (ii) a shift in diet with more vegetables, (iii) housing improvements with an extra story
or a corrugated roof, (iv) ability to afford children's school fees right through secondary school,
and (v) purchase of additional land. In addition to increased cash income for farm households,
local employment opportunities directly linked to agricultural marketing will increase. Small- to
medium-scale  farmers  are  responsive  to  new  commercial  opportunities  in  agriculture
introduced  under  the  Project.  The  commercial  orientation  of  the  Project  will  enable  farmers,
who  can  respond  to  new  opportunities,  to  absorb  and  disseminate  new  information  and
knowledge  among  their  group  members  and  other  farmers  in  their  villages.  Farmer  groups
usually include farmers of various landholdings. Poorer and marginal farmers will be gradually
involved in the process once tangible returns from the production and marketing of secondary
crops are demonstrated. Effective project implementation is essential to maximize the positive
impact  of  project  activities  on  the  reduction  of  rural  poverty.21  In  this  context,  continuous
monitoring of project activities needs to be ensured to enhance the project's impact.

2.

Gender and Development

106. Within  farmer  groups,  the  Project  will  promote  women’s  participation,  involvement  in
decision-making, and access to increased income. The Project recognizes the important role
of  women  farmers  in  agriculture,  and  the  social  and  cultural  constraints  to  their  effective
involvement in local institutions and economic initiatives. Project components are designed to
ensure women’s active participation in farmer groups, to promote their skills alongside men’s in
production  and  marketing,  and  to  facilitate  their  direct  access  to  project  benefits.  Support
measures have been designed to ensure that capacity building is based on specific needs that
women  have  identified.  These  include  women-only  forums,  development  of  literacy  and
numeracy  skills,  and  leadership  training  in  addition  to  the  interventions  that  focus  on
agriculture and market development.

private service providers, (ii) weak institutional capability of MOAC and DOA, (iii) shortage of

Success  in  effective  project  implementation  significantly  depends  on  the  institutional
capability of MOAC and DOA. This is well recognized as a major risk for the implementation of
agriculture  projects  in  Nepal,  where  the  sustainability  of  the  activities  and  impact  of  farmer
groups are seen to be low. A number of farmer groups were either poorly organized or inactive
due to (i) the lack of skills and training among the public extension workers on such specialized

often young JTs or JTAs, who lack practical experience with farmer groups. Such constraints
may  be  exacerbated  by  frequent  transfers  of  extension  staff,  who  thus  cannot  build  up  local

Project by (i) initiating regular seed planning workshops so that public institutions and private
seed  growers  and  traders  are  aware  of  farmers'  specific  needs  for  the  type  and  volume  of
seeds,  (ii)  supporting  pocket  areas  to  establish  commercial  seed  farms,  and  (iii)  fostering
private  seed  growers  and  nurseries  through  the  provision  of  training  and  seminars.  The
fundamental  issue  of  improving  NARC's  capability  to  provide  an  adequate  supply  of  good
quality seeds with high germination rates is being addressed under the World Bank’s AREP.

110.
The Project has been formulated based on the findings of the TA about the marketing

considered under the Project and addressed by (i) providing sufficient flexibility in the Project
design  so  that  farmers  will  be  able  to  adjust  their  production  patterns  to  accommodate

their  updated  market  conditions,  (iii)  providing  training  programs  and  study  tours  for
participating  farmer  groups  to  increase  their  awareness  of  potential  markets,  (iv)  supporting
agricultural fairs to promote improved contacts and interactions between growers and private
dealers, and (v) providing technical support for marketing sections of regional PIUs.

LESSONS LEARNED

A.

Overview

1.
Important lessons from agriculture projects and programs in Nepal are common across
projects  with  financing  from  external  funding  agencies.  The  Secondary  Crops  Development
Project (SCDP)1 financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the ongoing Agricultural
Research  and  Extension  Project  (AREP)  of  the  World  Bank  are  most  relevant  to  the  Project.
Under the SCDP, 108 farmer groups were formed with assistance from DOA's junior technical
assistants  (JTAs)  for  a  relatively  limited  technical  purpose  to  facilitate  the  organization  of
training programs, dissemination of information on technology, and marketing and production of
seeds.  Groups  were  formed  through  a  process  of  farmer  self-selection  and  participation.
Members  were  encouraged  to  start  group  funds,  which  have  been  built  up  mainly  through
contributions from project activities and partly from member savings. The group fund was used
for individual loans and, in a few cases, enterprising group leaders used the fund for collective
activities  (purchase  of  equipment  and  agricultural  inputs).  However,  these  farmer  groups  had
limited  effectiveness  due  to  (i)  weakness  because  JTAs  were  not  able  to  provide  adequate
social mobilization support; and (ii) lack of effective back-up services by JTAs, including training,
which  were  often  too  theoretical  and  based  on  group  lectures  and  discussions  rather  than
practical  demonstrations  and  follow-up  at  the  field  level.  Under  the  AREP  of  the  World  Bank,
similar  concerns  emerged.  A  number  of  lessons  relevant  to  the  Project  also  emerged  from
projects and programs of other funding agencies.2

Under  the  Project,  these  common  lessons  have  been  fully  considered  to  ensure  (i)  a
2.
sense  of  strong  ownership  among  local  communities  for  project  activities  through  workshops
with  the  prospective  beneficiaries,  and  (ii)  the  involvement  of  private  service  providers  for
effective  formation  and  strengthening  of  farmer  groups.  Close  monitoring  and  supervision  of
project  activities  will  be  required  during  implementation  through  field  team  supervisors  and
private service providers under the Project. Some of the major findings for lessons learned are
described below.

B.

Formation of Farmer Groups

3.
Community-based organizations have become central to many development initiatives in
Nepal.  They  are  central  to  the  new  paradigm  of  people-centered  development,  which  aims  to
respond to the demands of the beneficiaries and be genuinely participatory in that people at the
community  level  are  organized  to  be  increasingly  responsible  for  planning  activities  that  affect
them, and accessing and managing resources for the activities. Consequently, two factors are
to  be  taken  into  account  in  the  process  of  group  formation  and  development:  (i)  the  need  to
address issues of social mobilization and local governance, and (ii) the need to focus on specific
tasks or sets of activities. The main activities around which community groups are organized are
forestry, irrigation, rural finance, infrastructure maintenance, and agricultural marketing.

4.
Effective  formation  of  farmer  groups  requires  time,  intensive  interaction  with  farmers,
and appropriate guidance at the field level. Without such interactions, farmer groups tend to be
controlled and managed by a few elite and powerful members of the community. Some of these
influential people are so powerful that their actions may go against the spirit and purpose of the
group  concept.  Community  leaders  have  limited  skills  in  social  mobilization  and  do  not
necessarily respect group bylaws and plan the use of group funds in line with the needs of the
group.

5.
Informal  as  well  as  formal  groups  involved  in  community  management  need  to  be
provided  with  managerial  and  organizational  skills.  Lack  of  training  and  support  hampers  the
groups’  ability  to  take  more  responsibility  for  group  activities  and  management  of  local
resources. Devolution of decision-making to groups requires flexibility in program targeting and
budgeting.  Within  the  available  budget,  communities  and  groups  should  be  setting  their  own
targets,  selecting  from  several  technical  options.  A  self-help  attitude  needs  to  be  generated
among farmer groups. Groups are not ends in themselves. The purposes of farmer groups must
be  clear  and  focused,  and  this  usually  requires  technical  support  for  information  on  input
supplies and marketing.

6.
Women  must  be  explicitly  identified  as  full  members  of  community  groups  along  with
their  husbands  or  other  male  household  members.  Providing  membership  on  a  household
basis,  without  explicitly  including  the  women,  limits  their  participation  in  management  and
decision-making.  Having  women  as  executive  members  of  a  group  enhances  their  self-
confidence  and  social  status  and  can  be  effective  in  introducing  a  large  number  of  women  to
decision-making  processes.  However,  this  process  requires  time.  They  initially  need  special
training  in  order  to  participate  more  effectively  in  management.  Social  preparation  programs,
particularly on adult literacy and business skills, increase women’s confidence and status when
effectively  implemented.  For  these  reasons,  these  programs  are  required  at  an  early  stage  of
social preparation.

7.
In general, technical staff of Government agencies do not have proper skills, orientation,
or  time  to  handle  the  range  of  social  preparation  activities  initially  required  at  the  field  level  to
develop viable farmer groups, implement participatory interventions, manage conflict resolution,
and  promote  accountable  leadership.  Few  such  staff  are  sensitive  to  the  priorities  and  risk
among poor households in rural areas. District staff of line agencies are frequently transferred
and unlikely to be sustained at levels necessary for the intensive extension work required in the
formation  and  strengthening  of  farmer  groups.  Their  area  of  operations  is  the  provision  of
extension  services  on  technical  matters,  and  they  should  spend  more  time  on  improving  their
own technical knowledge and capabilities, and less on social mobilization activities.

C.

Private Service Providers

8.
Private  service  providers,  including  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  have  an
important role in facilitating group processes, spreading benefits more widely in the community,
involving  target  groups  such  as  women  and  poor  households,  and  negotiating  program
approaches  within  the  community.  Local  NGOs  may  not  have  the  required  skills  but  their
capacity  can  be  built  through  long-term  training  and  financial  inputs  from  national  or
international NGOs.

9.
Major  NGOs  have  developed  their  own  systematic  approaches  to  farmer  group
formation. Their approaches assist the various stages of group development, and aim at group

sustainability and self-management. Group development also requires technical back up, which
NGOs increasingly prefer to provide rather than rely on line agencies. With appropriate support,
farmer groups are effective in delivering production technology at the grassroots level and can
be a focal point for disseminating information on technology and marketing. A Canadian NGO is
carrying out such activities in partnership with national and local NGOs. Some major NGOs also
show that they can be effective in agricultural extension by providing intensive field-level support
by trained and motivated staff, over a relatively limited geographical area.

Other  issues  are  emerging  as  NGO  involvement  increases  and  community  groups
10.
evolve. In particular, due to differences in their approaches and the level of resources, there are
few institutional mechanisms for effective cooperation between line agencies and NGOs. Major
NGOs prefer to operate independently from the line agencies in separately demarcated areas,
and expect that any collaboration with line agencies has to be on the basis of equal partnership
and  accountability.  Government  line  agencies  particularly  at  the  local  level  often  tend  not  to
reciprocate  in  terms  of  partnership  and  accountability,  and  they  limit  NGOs'  involvement.
However,  there  are  a  few  cases  of  informal  arrangements  between  the  district  offices  of  the
Department  of  Agriculture  (DOA)  and  NGOs,  where  collaboration  is  effective  in  providing
training programs. It is thus important to gradually develop collaborative relationships between
government agencies and private service providers in phases under the Project.

D.

Agricultural Research

11.
The  World  Bank's  AREP  has  identified  some  weaknesses  in  the  existing  agricultural
research and extension system's development impact and implementation progress. First, there
is unnecessary duplication of research activities between regional agricultural research stations
of the National Agricultural Research Council (NARC). This is mainly due to the lack of proper
policy  and  strategy  for  national  agricultural  research.  There  seems  to  be  confusion  in  NARC
regarding  how  the  activities  of  their  research  stations  are  to  be  planned  and  coordinated.
Second, the bottom-up approach  in  planning of research to meet farmers’ needs is weak. For
this  purpose,  linkages  between  research  and  extension  exist  through  regular  interactions  at
village  workshops  and  regional  technical  working  groups.  Increased  efforts  are  required  to
strengthen  these  research-extension  linkages  through  the  improvement  of  a  holistic  approach
involving crops, livestock, agro-forestry, and off-farm activities.

12.
Under  the  Hill  Agriculture  Research  Project  financed  by  the  Government  of  the  United
Kingdom,  a  competitive  funding  system  was  introduced  to  promote  effective  agricultural
research.  In  addition  to  NARC,  other  research  providers,  including  NGOs  and  research
institutes,  are  becoming  involved  in  the  system,  and  other  external  funding  agencies  are
expressing interest in contributing to a national fund for agricultural research and development,
which  is  being  established.  The  competitive  funding  system  has  been  operational  since  1996
and successfully developed a system to obtain and assess research proposals with assistance
in  staff  training  and  other  project  inputs.  This  system  can  be  promoted  so  that  a  more
coordinated  and  client-oriented  research  activities  can  be  done  by  both  public  and  private
institutes.

13.
Research  outcomes  are  most  effectively  adopted  when  all  parties  are  committed  to
change and have a sense of "ownership" of the research and development process. There must
be  fewer  but  focused  programs,  addressing  client  needs  that  will  quickly  bring  measurable
impact.  There  is  a  need  to  move  away  from  a  researcher  dominated  and  Government-fund
driven  approach  to  research  to  a  more  responsive  competitive  grant  system  that  involves  the
eventual beneficiaries in identifying priority areas, selecting proposals, and financing research.

This  issue  is  being  considered  by  an  interministerial  committee  for  the  establishment  of  a
national research fund.

E.

Marketing and Postharvest Operations

14.
The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Cooperatives  does  not  have  adequate  resources  for
market  improvement  and  rehabilitation.  Local  resources  are  required  for  the  maintenance  of
such  infrastructure.  There  should  be  strong  local  ownership  for  activities  to  strengthen  market
infrastructure  by  consulting  potential  market  users  well  before  identifying  sites  and  designing
markets.  In  the  past,  siting  of  marketing  facilities  depended  on  land  availability  and  was  done
solely  by  Government  agencies  or  a  district  administration.  The  construction  of  marketing
facilities was target oriented rather than led by demand from the potential users. Although the
market  center  was  recommended  to  be  managed  by  farmer  groups,  the  Government  often
appointed  all  members  of  market  management  committees.  Some  chairpersons  of  these
committees  were  not  from  local  communities.  Farmers  and  traders  were  excluded  from  the
decision-making  process  as  market  rules  and  regulations  were  established.3  Thus,  the
involvement of local communities is essential from the initial planning stage for the rehabilitation
of existing market infrastructure.

15.
In  the  past,  demonstration  and  service  centers  were  constructed  with  the  intention  of
demonstrating  fruit  grading,  fruit  processing,  and  jam  making  to  project  beneficiaries.  These
facilities were to be operated under regional food laboratories. The facilities were constructed,
but much of the equipment provided was not used apparently because of the lack of personnel
who knew how to operate it. The location of these facilities was often not properly planned and,
as a result, was away from the fruit growing area. Efforts are needed to ensure that adequate
trained  staff  will  be  available  for  proposed  facilities,  and  that  the  facilities  are  appropriately
located to serve the production area. Under the Project, a postharvest operations specialist will
be recruited to assist the project staff in this regard.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

A.

Introduction

1.
The initial environmental examination (IEE) was conducted from June to July 1999 under
technical assistance financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The IEE report describes
the  environmental  determinants  of  the  project  area.  The  environmental  concerns  and  issues
related  to  the  Project  are  then  identified,  and  the  mitigative  measures  for  possible  adverse
impacts recommended in the report.

B.

Description of the Environment

2.
The  project  area  is  the  lowland  and  hilly  regions  of  12  districts.  The  hilly  region  is  a
broad zone with altitude ranging from 600 meters (m) to 3,000 m above sea level. This zone is
complex, with low to medium hills and mountains, river valleys, and tectonic valleys. In the hilly
region, food crops are grown on leveled or terraced lands mainly along river valleys, slopes, and
ridge  sides.2  Secondary  crops  are  concentrated  on  unirrigated  and  unleveled  slopes.  The
lowland  region  in  the  south  has  deep  alluvial  soils  deposited  by  rivers  flowing  from  hills  and
mountains.  The  northern  part  of  the  lowland  region  generally  consists  of  unconsolidated
materials mixed with boulders, pebbles, gravel, and sand making the formation very permeable,
and has an average gradient of about 2 percent to the south. The southern part of the lowland
region is much flatter, marking a change of soil texture to finer particles like clay.

Nepal has a monsoon season from June to September when about 60 to 80 percent of
3.
the  annual  rainfall  falls.  During  the  monsoon,  the  moisture-laden  air  from  the  Bay  of  Bengal
moves northwest and enters into the country from the southeast, giving heavy rainfalls. As the
air  moves  west,  its  moisture  is  gradually  reduced.  Thus,  the  western  part  of  the  country
generally  has  less  rainfall.  The  postmonsoon  period  from  October  to  November  has  the  least
amount of precipitation. During winter from December to February, the temperature goes down
substantially and varies with altitude. The premonsoon season from March to May is mostly hot
and dry. The maximum temperature in the lowland region often exceeds 40 degrees centigrade.
These  seasonal  changes  in  climate  and  ecological  differences  between  regions  provide
opportunities for the production and marketing of a variety of agricultural and horticultural crops
in Nepal.

Gender and  Agriculture Development

7.
The  gender  issue  in  agriculture  development  is  whether  women’s  contribution  in
agricultural production can be translated into their having access to and control over income and
resources  such  as  technology  and  inputs.  In  Nepal,  such  access  and  control  are  constrained
through  a  number  of  practices  and  social  conditions.    Men  are  traditionally  responsible  for
plowing  and  women  for  the  ensuing  tasks  of  planting,  composting,  weeding,  and  postharvest
activities. Women are the main decision-makers for these activities. Harvesting is usually done
by all family members. It is estimated that women’s contribution to crop production in terms of
time  and  efforts  is  about  half  or  less,  and  their  contribution  to  kitchen  gardening  and  ginger
production is more than 70 percent.5

responsible  for  the  production  and  application  of  organic  manure.  Men  also  have  control  over

region,  the  conversion  of  areas  from  cereal  crops  like  millet  and  maize  into  a  range  of
vegetables and citrus fruits may lead to a substantial increase in cash income. Some farmers in
the hilly region, who were interviewed during project processing, marketed fresh vegetables in
the border towns in the lowland region and easily doubled their cash income.

10.
The income analysis shows that the present net income of about NRs12,100 under the
without-Project  situation  will  increase  to  about  NRs17,400  or  by  44  percent  under  the  Project.
This  increase  is  largely  brought  about  by  the  expansion  of  vegetable  production,  and  by  the
introduction of leguminous crops. As important items of agricultural exports to the Indian market,
many farmers in the lowland region grow lentils and peas. In the hilly region, the net income is
expected to increase from about NRs9,500 in the without-Project situation to about NRs15,800,
or by 66 percent, under the Project. The increase is mainly due to the expansion of cash crops
with  good  marketing  potential  like  fresh  vegetables,  by  converting  areas  used  for  millet  and
wheat  production.  The  returns  on  investment  in  two  typical  multiyear  fruit  crops,  including
banana  for  the  lowland  region  and  citrus  fruits  for  the  hilly  region,  were  separately  estimated
based on their flows of production costs and revenue. The analysis estimates that the financial
rate  of  return  for  banana  cultivation  at  51  percent  and  that  for  citrus  fruits  at  26  percent.  The
analysis also shows that the return on the daily family labor will be substantially higher than the
basic wage rate, which is expected to be in the range of NRs50-75.

The  aggregate  incremental  net  income  has  also  been  estimated  for  the  production
11.
pocket  areas  as  a  whole.  As  a  result  of  crop  diversification,  consolidated  net  financial  income
increases by NRs230 million ($3.3 million) from the eighth year onwards. The gain in net income
in  the  hilly  region  is  higher  than  that  for  the  lowland  region  because  of  higher  potential  for
growing horticultural crops in the hilly region.

12.
Overall project costs include investment and recurrent costs for the project activities over
a period of six years. The recurrent expenditures include costs for repairs and maintenance of
buildings, vehicles, and equipment purchased under the Project, and are carried on beyond the
Project  at  the  annual  rate  of  2.5  percent  of  cost  for  buildings  and  5  percent  for  vehicles,
furniture,  and  equipment.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  for  the  Project  over  20  years  is
estimated  at  16.1  percent  and  the  financial  net  present  value  at  a  12  percent  discount  rate  is
NRs214 million ($3.1 million).

E.

Economic Analysis

Economic  prices  of  outputs  are  estimated  at  their  border  price  less  duties  and  taxes
13.
such  as  the  value  added  tax  at  a  flat  rate  of  10  percent  on  incremental  value  added  at  each
processing stage. The full foreign exchange cost of the balance plus non-foreign exchange cost
(i.e.,  Nepalese  rupee  costs  such  as  port  handling,  transport,  and  labor  associated  with
nontradable  items)  then  comprises  the  economic  price.  The  nontradable  items,  including
transportation costs and labor, are converted into economic prices with the use of the standard
conversion factor of 0.9 as generally adopted for project analysis in Nepal.

Farmgate  fertilizer  costs  used  in  the  crop  budgets  are  based  on  the  cessation  of  all
14.
subsidies from 1 November 1999, and fertilizer prices for the year 2000 forecast by the World
Bank  at  constant  1999  prices.  Economic  prices  exclude  taxes  and  are  based  on  the  standard
conversion  factor  on  non-foreign  exchange  costs  after  the  deduction  of  taxes.  Transport
expenses were calculated for the lowland region and for the hilly region separately. Costs are
based on actual freight charges for a range of lowland and hilly locations and destinations. The
cost per load is NRs858 in the lowland region and NRs1,855 in the hilly region. Unit transport
costs in the lowland region is NRs2.2 per ton per kilometer (km) and NRs3.5 per ton/km in the

hilly region. Project vehicle operations and maintenance costs are NRs10/km, NRs300,000 per
vehicle per year, with foreign exchange cost at 70 percent, local cost 10 percent, and taxes at
20 percent.

The net economic benefits form the eighth year were estimated at NRs260 million ($3.8
15.
million).  Conversion  of  financial  to  economic  costs  results  in  a  reduction  in  project  costs  by
about 10 percent. Coupled with benefits for farmers, the economic internal rate of return for the
Project is 19.6 percent and the economic net present value is NRs389 million ($5.6 million). A
shadow wage rate of 0.80 for unskilled labor, which is used for such labor in the western region,
will further improve the Project's economic viability.

16.
Under  the  Project,  all  financial  benefits  will  be  distributed  to  farmers  and  agricultural
laborers although there will be a marginal portion of revenue recovered from the farmers' use of
regional  laboratory  facilities.  The  Government  will  incur  all  financial  costs  of  the  Project.  In
Nepal,  the  poverty  line  is  officially  defined  as  the  income  required  to  purchase  the  daily
minimum requirement of 2,124 calories per capita, which is estimated at NRs4,404 in 1999. In
the Midwestern and Far Western development regions where the Project will be implemented,
the majority of farmers are either below or near the poverty line. Under the Project, at least 50
percent of group members in each pocket area will be poor households. Based on this, the net
present  value  of  total  economic  gains  accruing  to  poor  households  under  the  Project  will  be
NRs525  million  ($7.6  million)  or  NRs11,600  ($168)  per  household.  In  addition,  during  the
selection  of  poor  farmers  for  the  inclusion  in  a  farmer  group,  priority  will  be  given  to  the
disadvantaged  members  of  the  local  community,  including  the  former  bonded  agricultural
laborers.
